title: 110_hr7267
content: The "Mortgage Credit Repair Act of 2008" may be cited as such. Key findings are outlined in the Act. The United States housing bubble burst in 2005 due to high default rates on subprime and adjustable rate mortgages. Mortgages with negative amortization or lending fraud have high foreclosure rates. The housing bubble burst in 2005 due to high default rates on subprime and adjustable rate mortgages. Mortgages obtained through lending fraud, incomplete documentation, and changing terms at closing also contributed to high foreclosure rates. Standard debt ratios were not always met. The housing bubble burst in 2005 due to high default rates on subprime and adjustable rate mortgages, as well as lending fraud and incomplete documentation. Borrowers with mortgages exceeding 36% front-end ratios faced foreclosures and bankruptcies, impacting credit history for up to 7 years. Borrowers affected by bad mortgages leading to foreclosure should have the chance to rebuild credit. Borrowers impacted by foreclosure should have the opportunity to rebuild credit without long-lasting effects on their responsible borrowing practices. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to define "front end ratio" as the portion of an individual's income used for mortgage payments. Additionally, special circumstance relief is provided for borrowers impacted by foreclosure. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include cases under title 11 or the Bankruptcy Act that predate the report by more than 3 years if specific criteria are met, including a consumer's front-end debt ratio being 37% or higher. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to exclude adverse information like closed accounts, collections, repossessions, and foreclosures if specific criteria are met, including bankruptcy filed after January 1, 2004, and no disputes made since then. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to exclude adverse information for new accounts and transactions added after the first payment due date on the consumer's mortgage note, where the front end ratio becomes 37% or higher, not added more than 6 months after a foreclosure on the consumer's primary residence or March 31, 2009, and if the consumer notifies the consumer reporting agency directly before March 31, 2009. SEC. 5 of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include paragraphs (1), (3), (4), (5), and (7) in subsection (b) of section 605.
